dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe's car pulls in to the curb. Terry gets out, lifts the suitcase from the back seat, leans back in to shake hands with Marlowe, and walks away along the street, carrying the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe looks after Terry, shakes his head, then does a U-turn and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest old-fashioned stucco house on a street, say, above Franklin. Marlowe drives up and is about to pull into the open garage when two men step out of it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cL

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: and stop him. They're plainclothesmen, detectives. SERGEANT GREEN leans on the window.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: Your name Marlowe?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Green flashes his ID.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: Let's go inside. We want to talk to you, He opens the car door, indicating that Marlowe shall get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the key in the lock. The door opens. The second cop steps in first, looks around; satisfied the place is empty, he nods and Mariowe and Green come in.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: Sit down, Marlowe. Marlowe stands. The cops shrug and sit down.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: I'm Sergeant Green, this is Detective Dayton. Where did you go last night? Dayton has a notebook and pen. Marlowe lights a cigarette. -

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: This is where I say, What's all this about? And you say, We ask the questions.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: So just answer them. Where did you go last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Maybe if I knew why you want to know, I could remember,

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: He tosses license.

dialogues.speaker: DAYTON
dialogues.text: Are you gainfully employed, Mr. Marlowe? (a beat) Where do you work?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I understand English, believe it or not. I'ma private detective, I run my own agency. his wallet to Dayton, open to show his Dayton looks at it, passes it silently to Green, who glances at it and drops it on a table.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: You know a man named Terry Lennox,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Who says I do?

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: His address book, And there's a red Maserati parked at the bottom of the hill...registered to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: So where did you go last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Let me see. I went down to a joint on Franklin and had a hamburger and a cup of coffee...the hamburger wasn't very good. I came back here and ran off Khatchaturyan's violin concerto...I don't like it...and played a game of chess against Wilhelm Steinitz.

dialogues.speaker: DAYTON
dialogues.text: (writing) Wilhelm Steinitz...address?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He's been dead for 72 years. I lost. What else do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: oo c2 CONTD (2)

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: What time did Terry Lennox come here?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I didn't say he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green rises to face Marlowe. Unobtrusively Dayton circles around in back of Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN
dialogues.text: Look, Marlowe. You've been gone along time. I know, because I've missed half a night's sleep waiting for you to come back. Now you tell me where you were. ‘ MARLOWE I don't have to tell you anything, Sergeant Green. Jf you have a ¢ specific charge against me, state it. Otherwise, buggar off. o~ GREEN Dayton, do we have a specific charge against Mr. Marlowe? Dayton shoves Marléwe from behind, hard, into Green, who staggers back and falls to his hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: DAYTON
dialogues.text: (grinning) Now we do.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, you can't pull that one...

dialogues.text: Dl INSERT = DAY Ly A man's hand writing on a form; we see a blue uniform Ge? sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assaulting a police officer in the performance of his duty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portion of the wall and one corner. Marlowe slams into the wall from o.s. with considerable force, rolls into the corner, and tries to regain his balance.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: My God, you're clumsy, Marlowe...

dialogues.speaker: INT, INTERROGATION ROOM
dialogues.text: A small bleak room with table and chairs. Marlowe, DET. LT. FARMER, a DETECTIVE.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Always tripping over something.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (bleeding slightly from the nose) Yeah. Farmer takes him firmly by the arm and sits him down.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Just sit down and stay there, We don't want you all banged up, some- body might get the wrong impression. Now tell me, Marlowe...why won't you answer a simple question?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Two reasons. First, it isn't simple. Second, I don't like the way you ask it. He has taken out a pack of cigarettes. He starts to light one. Farmer snatches them away.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: You crazy, rotting your lungs out with those things? Don't you know what they do to you? Besides, they stink up the place. Knowing Marlowe is a heavy smoker, he's going to let him suffer, FARMER . All right, I'm going to give you one more chance. Where did you go last night, and why?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: One more chance before what?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Before I throw the book at you. ’ MARLOWE I'm waiting to hear the charges.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Oh, don't give me that innocent crap. You want me to believe your friend Terry Lennox turned up in the middle of the night and you drove him a few hundred miles to. somewhere, and he never told you?

dialogues.speaker: \ MARLOWE
dialogues.text: : Told me what?

dialogues.speaker: PARMER
dialogues.text: You want to hear the charges? Okay. Accessory after the fact of murder...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Who's dead?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: »..aiding a felon in unlawful flight...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: ‘ I asked you, Lieutenant. Who's dead?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Terry Lennox' wife, that's who's dead, And not very nice dead. He snaps his fingers at the Number Two cop, who passes him some b/w glossies out of a folder. The Lieutenant gives these to Marlowe, who is revolted. He puts them down.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: { I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: You have to believe she's dead, that's i obvious. So what don't you believe? Cc MARLOWE That Terry Lennox did it.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: You don't believe he could beat a woman to death,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: How long have you known him?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Long enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: ‘He's a gambler, mixed up with people like Marty Augustine. All the dirty pools, football, baseball, basketball, hockey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gambler, yes. A killer, no. He loved his wife.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: ‘They split up once before.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: They were divorced.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: They remarried, They had their ~ troubles, who doesn't? But they loved each other.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Was she cheating on him?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Was he cheating on her?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Same answer.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Don't know much about your old pail, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The Lennoxes have money, I don't, and I don't like freeloaders. These days, Terry and I have a drink together once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Last night, what did he tell you... that he was in a jam with his - gambling associates? Marlowe doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: That he was fighting with his wife again? . (no answer) What excuse did he give you? {no answer) Oh, the heli with it. (tosses Marlowe's cigarettes at him) Here, go stink up a cell. (to other cop} Take him out and book him.

dialogues.speaker: INT, JAIL CELL
dialogues.text: Marlowe, alone in the cell, lies on the bunk, smoking, His clothes look as though he'd slept in them...he has -»-his shirt is soiled, he has a three-day growth of beard. He turns his head wearily as footsteps sound in the corridor. : A warder appears at the door, unlocks it and swings it open.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: Okay, on your feet. Marlowe gets up, feeling some tender spots.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: More questions? I don't know which'll give first, me or that wall.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: Never mind. Move it. Marlowe leaves the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corner of a dingy room with a counter. A uniformed cop is dumping the contents of a manila envelope onto the counter; Marlowe's wallet, keys, etc. Marlowe checks the wallet. The warder is looking on.

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED COP
dialogues.text: All in order?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED COP
dialogues.text: Sign here. Marlowe signs, Looking at the warder.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What goes on?

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: You're loose, buster. Ain't that enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No, not after three days of getting bounced around. I want to see the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: What Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You know damn well what Lieutenant, Farmer, the one who's been doing all the pushing.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: 0, him. Well, you go through there and ask the desk sergeant. (to uniformed cop) Some people are just never satisfied. cur To  11 a Dé INT. CORRIDOR ~- POLICE DEPARTMENT - DAY Marlowe is looking at doors. At the other end of the corridor Farmer and another MAN come out of an office and start toward Marlowe, not seeing him; they're deep in conversation. Marlowe sees them and quickens his pace.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: (to other man) +»+.get a make on those prints, and tell Ballistics to hurry it up. If we can match.,.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Lieutenant...

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: {impatient at being ‘ interrupted) i Yes? Oh, it's you. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're dropping the charges against wo me?

dialogues.speaker: . FARMER
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why? All of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Because we're no longer interested in you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (follows them along the corridor) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PARMER
dialogues.text: We got all our answers.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But what about Terry Lennox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i FARMER He's dead, Marlowe, The case is o~ closed,

dialogues.speaker: D6
dialogues.text: El

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Terry...dead? How? What do you mean, the case... But Farmer and the other man have stepped into a lift and the doors close in his face.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch...!

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He is buying a paper from a coin-op box. ORGAN the crime reporter walks up-to him.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: You won't find anything in that. We've got fresher murders.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Morgan. Happenstance?

dialogues.speaker: NORGAL
dialogues.text: No, I heard they were springing you this morning. Got a way to .get home?

dialogues.speaker: HARLOWE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) These bastards are reali good at bringing you in, but they don't care how you get back.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAL
dialogues.text: I can give you a lift. Got a couple of back issues you might want to see.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWS
dialogues.text: I want to know what happened to Terry Lennox. HORGAN . They didn't tell you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Like you say, they've got fresher murders. All I heard was that he's dead and the case is closed. MORGAN. You wasted your three days, Marlowe. My car's across the street, — cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A newspaper in Marlowe's hands; front page with head- line, LENNOX SUICIDE, a photo of Terry and a woman, Sylvia. A smaller headline says Admits Killing Wife.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Suicide!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan driving through Los Angeles streets.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Blew his brains out in some god- forsaken little Mexican town. He left a full confession...

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: IT can read.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Marlowe,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why should you be sorry? It's just another story to you.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry because you're stupid. You sat in the pokey taking lumps for your friend, and your friend let you down. Stupid, Marlowe, but it's a kind of stupidity I like. We ran a story on you, by the way. It's there, picture and all. ‘ He indicates a second newspaper on the seat between them. Marlowe gives it a cursory glance.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. That'll help business a lot. (returns to story of Terry Lennox) Otatoclan. Where the hell is Otatoclan?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I'm not just sure, but it's way back in, Caters mostly to hunters, I think.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why would he go there? He could have killed himself right in Tijuana.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: “Tijuana, huh? That's where I figured you took him. Hell, he could have killed himself right here in L.A. The man was at the end of his rope, Marlowe, You can't figure what they'll do. They don't know themselves,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What happened to the body?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: His wife's family didn't want it back, for obvious reasons. I guess he didn't have any family of his own,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: There was an aunt, but she's dead.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: So he's buried at Otatoclan. No morgue facilities there...they shovel ‘em under real fast.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Case closed. All tied up with a little blue bow on top. Shit! Terry wasn't at the end of his rope. And the way he talked, Sylvia wasn't dead then, either. I don't believe it. I don't believe he killed his wife, I don't believe he killed himself.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Evidence?

dialogues.speaker: ES
dialogues.text: Fl

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I knew the man. Morgan, you've been on the crime beat for years. Doesn't this smell to you at all...not even - one little bit?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Not to me, not to the cops. Marlowe ...when you get home, take a hot shower, get stinking drunk...and forget it. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe, scrubbed and shaved, is working assiduously on a bottle of bourbon, but his manner is restless and uneasy. He can't get drunk and forget it. He looks up a number in the phone book, and dials.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello...Fairway Travel Service? Yes...I was thinking of a trip to Mexico. I want to go to a place called Otatoclan. That's right... Ontwa-t-o0...

dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING a dusty, remote Mexican village.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR -
dialogues.text: I myself made the examination and signed the documents. I am coroner here as well as doctor. You may wish to look at these photographs. He hands two b/w prints to Marlowe.  16 eo F3 INSERT The photographs in Marlowe's hands. The one uppermost shows the body of Terry Lennox, largely nude, lying in a crude wooden coffin, packed in ice. A blackened wound shows on the temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | @3 Our facilities are limited. It was necessary to bring ice from the hotel... Marlowe shuffles the photographs, bringing uppermost a close shot of Terry's head, packed in ice, wich an ugly contact wound showing clearly on the temple. The doctor's hand enters SHOT, pointing.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: You see...Death was instantaneous.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I see. (returns photos) The gun? o~ . ‘ . JEFE Was his, registered to him in Los Angeles County.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You gentlemen are being very kind. I hope it's not too much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: We are most happy, Mr. Narlowe. You ' were a friend of the deceased,

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: i I'm grateful. As I understand it, : Terry Lennox checked into the hotel, was shown to his room, and about an hour later he shot himself,

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How did he get here...to Otatoclan? , Blank faces. c

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 17 ef F4 —s CONTD

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: There are only two ways for the tourist...the small charter plane from Tijuana and the way I came, by the hired jeep. I asked around. Terry Lennox didn't fly, and he didn't hire the jeep. So how did he get here?

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: This is a mystery, Mr. Marlowe. We don't know how he came,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Somebody must have brought him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: It would seem so.

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But nobody saw who it was. : The Jefe spreads his nands. And nobody saw anyone come into the hotel, or go to Terry's room.

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: The answer I received was no. You may ask there yourself, Mr. Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I already have. Can I see Terry Lennox' effects?

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: ‘ Certainly. He takes a small box out of a drawer and empties it on the desk; wallet, keys, handkerchief. Marlowe w opens the wallet. It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: : He had a suitcase,

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: Por favor? Cr CONTINUED  Cc F4

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: When he checked into Where is it? A suitcase. the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, the suitcase. It was not in his room. I regret to say it, but thines disappear. I questioned ths hotel staff, of course, but...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It may surprise you, but things disappear in New York and L.A., too, You're sure Lennox didn't contact anyone here in town? No phone calls, no messages?

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: Not that I know of. What else can I show you? Fingerprints... {shows Marlowe a set of prints} A stat of these was sent to your Los Angeles police...they match those of Lennox on file there. I believe he had been engaged in...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Gambling. Yes. Can I see the note? The Jefe extracts it from the open file folder on his desk whence the other items have come.

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: It was on the desk beside him, A stat of this was also sent. It is without doubt his handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I wonder how carefully they checked that. They wouldn't want to find . it wasn't. (examines note) Short and to the point. Suicide note and full confession, all in a few well-chosen words. No incoherent rambling, no hysterics. He must have had nerves of steel.

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: You are suggesting something, Mr. Marlowe?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cc F4

dialogues.speaker: F5
dialogues.text: Cc ro

dialogues.speaker: F6
dialogues.text: Gl ed

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm suggesting that handwriting can be forged, and that murder can be made to look like suicide. I'm suggesting that I'd like to know who brought Terry Lennox here, and why. I'm suggesting, Senor Jefe, that someone is lying.

dialogues.speaker: JEFE
dialogues.text: Mr. Marlowe...! -

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (forestalling the man's anger, gives him a business card) If you ever find out who it is, I'd appreciate it if you'd iet me know. Thank you for your time, gentlemen. And...which way is the cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those bleak little Mexican cemeteries, the wooden crosses gay with ribbons and holy pictures. Marlowe stands with an OLD MEXICAN MAN beside a fresh, unmarked grave. In sign language Marlowe indicates that he wants a cross made for the grave. The old man nods. Marlowe gives him some money, then takes out a notebook and pen and begins to print.

dialogues.text: The notebook page. Marlowe prints in block letters, TERENCE LENNOX d. 1972.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door. It opens. We see the legend painted on it: PHILIP MARLOWE PRIVATE INVESTIGATIONS. Marlowe comes in, shuts the door, and takes the mail out of the box under the door-slot.

dialogues.text: This is the Southside Finance Company. Mr. Marlowe, we're calling in regard to your overdue... He shuts it off, and begins to go through the mail, dropping the junk stuff into the wastebasket. One item offers him some especially fine Swedish porno, complete with a picture brochure; he studies this as though wondering what they won't do next. The phone RINGS. He answers it.

dialogues.text: Marlowe speaking... Yes... (makes a note) Mrs. Roger Wade. ... Well, that would depend on the nature of the case, Mrs. Wade. ... Sorry, I don't do divorce work. ... I see. Have you filed a missing persons report with the police? «+» Uh-huh, I understand. All right, Mrs. Wade, I guess I can work it in. When would you like to meet? ... Oh, I think so. What's the address?

dialogues.text: A fairly sumptuous home, suitable for a best-selling author. Marlowe leaves his car and rings the doorbell. A MAID opens the door.

dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.text: My name is Marlowe, Philip Marlowe.

dialogues.text: The foyer, as Marlowe enters.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And you didn't worry.

dialogues.text: Not at first, no. Roger has a drinking problem. Every so often he reaches a stage where he feels~ he must have professional help.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Isn't there a particular place where he goes? A doctor who takes care of him?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Yes, But this time he didn't go there. I've checked every other place I could think of...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And still you didn't-worry.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Are you implying something, Mr. Marlowe? :

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Oniy that you might have felt you deserved a few days‘ rest. I don't think you got those bruises running into a door.

dialogues.text: There's no need to go into all that. I wasn't worried because he's disap- peared like this before...he never would teli me where he'd been. It seems to be a very private thing with him. I found this in his wastepaperbasket. It might help. She hands him a yellow second sheet that has been crumpled and then smoothed out again.

dialogues.text: Doctor V...Doctor V...a whole long string of V's...all in caps...YoU HUST HELP ME. Who is Doctor V?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: That's what I want you to find out. Who he is, where he is, and what sort of hold he has over Roger.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You think this is the same man he's gone to before, on these private trips?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I'm only guessing, of course.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It's a reasonable assumption. Doctor V...

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Not much to go on, is it? I looked in the directory under Physicians... I never knew there were so many names beginning with V.

dialogues.speaker: G5
dialogues.text: al

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I think the one we want will belong to a very small group of very dis- creet specialists. He may not be too difficult to find. Can you give me a picture of your husband?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: ¥es, of course. This is the latest one.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not a forgettable face.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: He's a very large man. Sometimes I think that's part of his trouble. We haven't discussed money yet, Mr. Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Fifty dollars a day, and expenses. He gets violent when he drinks?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I wish I could deny that, but I can't. I'll give you a check now, if you like,

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks, I prefer an itemized bill. That way there's no misunderstanding. Okay, Mrs. Wade. I'll get on this right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A discreet sign on a building front: THE CARNE ORGANIZA- TION, INC. CONFIDENTIAL ENQUIRIES.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Confidential enquiries! Kee-rist,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be the corridor of any modern business concern, reeking of chrome-steel efficiency. The Carne opera tives we see are proper gentlemen, neatly dressed, emphasizing Marlowe's shabbiness. From o.s. we hear the subdued clatter of business machines. Marlowe walks along the corridor, opens a door.  25 Cc H3 INT. OFFICE - CARNE ORGANIZATION - DAY ' A small office room furnished in Spartan Modern. A t very efficient~looking WOMAN sits behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ' WOMAN
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Name's Marlowe...private detective on a case... (shows her his license) I need some information.

dialogues.speaker: ' WOMAN
dialogues.text: | What sort of information, Mr. ... um, ..Marlowe?

dialogues.speaker: ' MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Nothing that will tarnish the Carne Organization's shining image, I ' . assure you. I only want some names : from your barred-window file. Cc . WOMAN ' I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: | | The barred-window file. The list of doctors who specialize in treat- ing rich alcoholics and borderline psychos. My client is trying to lecate a husband who answers that aescription. I'm only interested in the V's.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (making note) You did say Vee.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: V as in Vera.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Have a seat, Mr. Marlowe. I'll run the cards through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits through an inner door. Marlowe lights a u cigarette, looks for an ashtray, can't find one, and Cc uses the pot containing a plastic philodendron. The woman returns with three punch cards.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 26 Cc H3 © «CONTD

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Vukanich, Varley, and Verringer. She begins to type names and addresses,

dialogues.speaker: _ MARLOWB
dialogues.text: Just like that. Think of the time and shoeleather if I'd had to track them down myself.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: We consider ourselves efficient, Mr. Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The organization spirit. You don't suppose Nr. Carne could use an in- efficient but very experienced private eye like me?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Personnel is down the hall, third Cc door on your right.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Your tone lacks that certain spark. Perhaps I'd better wait till I get my other suit back from the cleaners. The woman is now operating an adding machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be sixteen dollars and fifty cents, Pay at the desk. She hands him the typed sheet and the slip.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe is eating his lunch out of a paper bag and making a phone call,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Cc Mrs. Wade? Marlowe. I have three names.. Vukanich...Varley...Verringer. Any of them ring a bell? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: MARLOWE (Coritd) (obviously the answer is no} Uh-huh. Okay, I'1l start touring. ...Yes, I will, Mrs. Wade. Just as soon as I do. He gulps the last of his coffee from a paper cup, sweeps the debris into the wastepaperbasket. As an afterthought, he checks the automatic message-recorder.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: This is the Southside Finance Company again, Mr. Marlowe... He cuts off the message and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe's car driving in past an identifying sign. The spa looks more like a motel than a hospital; low build- ings, trees, grass, a pool, Marlowe stops in front of what seems to be the main office and gets out. There are people about in the grounds, sunning beside the pool, strolling, sitting in deck chairs. Instead of going into the office, Marlowe starts walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe prowling around the grounds, looking at people... leoking for Roger Wade, He doesn't see anything resen- bling Roger, but a well-endowed young lady in a brief bikini catches his eye. He stares; she lifts her sun- glasses and glares; and a voice speaks behind Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: Looking for someone?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE AND VERRINGER
dialogues.text: As Marlowe turns to meet DR. VERRINGER...a small man, quiet-spoken, with a gentle manner. VERRINGER <« I'm Dr. Verringer.

dialogues.speaker: HARLOWE
dialogues.text: How do you do. My name's Marlowe. I'd like to see Roger Wade.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: Suppose we step over here, Mr. Marlowe. They go apart, where they can speak privately.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: Now...who did you want to see?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Roger Wade.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: There's no one here by that name.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He may not be using it. Recognize this? He shows Roger's photo to Verringer, who scarcely glances at it. .

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: No, May I ask what your business is, Mr. Marlowe?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: If he's not here, what do you care?

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: This is a hospital. I dislike strangers prowling about.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (shows his license} I'm working for Mrs. Roger Wade. She'd like her husband back.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I can't help you. Politely but firmly he indicates that Marlowe shall return to his car. They walk to it together. Marlowe gets in,

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: Good day, Mr. Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sorry I bothered you, Doctor. He drives away. Verringer watches to make sure he goes.  29 1 Cc Kl INT. WADE LIVING ROOM - EVENING ' Marlowe and Eileen.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: But how can you be so sure he‘s 1 at Verringer's? You didn't see hin...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: We had three possibilities, right? Dr. Vukanich, Dr. Varley, Dr. Verringer. Dr. Vukanich and Dr. Varley were helpful and cooperative, \ not because they fell in love with my baby blue eyes but because they wanted to clear their skirts.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: : You mean, in case something has : happened to Roger... ‘ MARLOWE y! They wanted me to know that it ' hadn't happened at their places. ¢ They couldn't show me their admis- l sion records, of course, but they ‘ let me show the photograph around , and ask questions. Verringer didn't even bother to look at the photo- graph, he just threw me out.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: But if Roger is there, why wouldn't he say so? i MARLOWE Because for some reason he doesn't want Roger found just yet. Why don't you let me take you out there, Mrs. Wade? Verringer could hardly brush you off the way he did me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, I haven't the guts. Besides, : Roger wouldn't...I'm not a good ‘ influence on him. .He does much better with strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc I couldn't make him leave, unless he wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kl Ll 30 contD

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: You could find out how he is, and what's going on, and then we'd know better what to do, wouldn't we? Believe me, Mr. Marlowe...if I go out there and make a big scene, Roger will feel compelled to make a bigger one. I'11 back you up if there's any trouble. But I don't think you're afraid of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What gave you that idea?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I read about you in the newspaper. I liked what you did.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's why you called me, instead of one of the big outfits like Carne. I wondered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seemed to me that you were a man who could be trusted.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can do, It may take a while.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I'il be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe drives up. The gate across the driveway is now shut and padiocked. Marlowe pulls the car off to one side and kills the motor. He opens the glove- box and then gets out, holding a picklock.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: At the gate. He maneuvres the chain on which the padlock is secured until he can get hold of the lock; then he proceeds to open it with the picklock, He pushes the gate open and goes through. -  by

dialogues.speaker: LS
dialogues.text: L6é 31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe approaches the office. It's dark except for a single light. He tries the door; it's locked. He knocks, Nothing happens. He looks around, rather baffled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patients' quarters are dark. Marlowe moves silently through the grounds...and sees one lighted room. He goes toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light is coming from a glass wall, partly covered by a floor-length drape but open at one side where the sliding door is pushed back to admit air. Marlowe makes his way quietly onto the terrace outside the open door. Keeping in the shadows, he can both ,see and hear what goes on in the room beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasant room, furnished with a bed, dresser, chair. Dr. Verringer is talking with ROGER WADE, who sits on the bed. Roger is a huge man, who looks tough and mean .».-but at the moment he seems perfectly cowed by the small soft-spoken doctor. This may be because he is under some sedation.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: It's too much, Doc. You want too much.

dialogues.speaker: VBRRINGER
dialogues.text: That was the agreed price, Roger. You knew that when you came here.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but...

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: You needed me very badly when you came here, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I did, goddam it, but it's too fucking much...

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: You know better than to use that kind of language to me,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lé

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...but five thousand dollars...!

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: You'd like to go home, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Christ, if I stay in this Pen much longer I'll start smashing the walls. !

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: You don't smash things, not in my place. A man came looking for you today...a private detective. Your wife is trying to find you. I don't think you want your wife to know too much about your reasons for coming here.

dialogues.speaker: . ROGER
dialogues.text: ZI don't want that bitch to know anything.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: Here is your checkbook, here is a pen. The check's made out, all you have to do is sign it. I'll send you home in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (whining) You're extorting from me, Doc... that's what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: "You try my patience. You really do, Sign it, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marlowe speaks from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just let that wait a while? (opens screen door and enters) But you know, I'm almost inclined to agree with him, Dr. Verringer. Do you always get your bills paid this way?

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: None of your damned business, and how dare you break in here like this? I could...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You could have me arrested for trespassing, but why go to all that bother?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Who the heil are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Marlowe...the man who was here today looking for you. The good doctor dummied up. I see why now.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: You don't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (assessing the change in the situation) Yeah. Yeah, the son of a bitch won't let me go. He wants money. Five thousand goddam separate and distinct dollars...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: _T heard.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: You don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I understand that Mr. Wade wants to: leave, and you're holding him pending payment of five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You going to get me out of here?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: If that's what you want me to do.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You bet your sweet ass. (to Verringer) I got somebody on my side now, Doc. (MORE) .

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 34 oe L?— CONTD (2) ROGER (Contd) ' , What're you going to do about it, huh? Stick me with another goddam ' fucking needle?

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: No, I'm not going to do that. Very well, I suppose I can't stop you... not without a noisy scene and a lot of unpleasantness. But I want you to understand, Roger...You have not heard the end of this.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: ' Ah, go screw. Taking his checkbook, Roger heaves himself up and flings ' an arm around Marlowe's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: ' Come on, little buddy. Let us fly : from this shithouse before he turns 1 us both into giant snails. You got Ce a car? :

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: : It's a little way. Can you make it?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Don't you worry, o1' Roger'll make it. (waving the checkbook) Goodbye, Dr. V. Ml EXT. WADE HOUSE - NIGHT Marlowe's car in front of the house, Marlowe holding the passenger door while Roger unloads himself, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: The look on his face when I went off with the checkbook...did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers and Marlowe steadies him... .

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I saw it. Come on. ce . CONTINUED  35

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I bet he's eating his goddam ass off right now... The front door opens, spilling light across the drive- way. Eileen stands in the doorway. ty x 2

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You opening doors now? What the hell am I paying the goddam maid for?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: It's late, Roger, she's gone home.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: But you waited up. Oh, she's noble, Marlowe. She is so goddam noble she can make a man puke.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Roger, will you please come inside?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Afraid I'll disturb the neighbors, huh? (shouts) Hey, all you little fucks! Wake up. I'm home again. iARLOWE Inside. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Roger and Marlowe enter, not gracefully.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He's still groggy from the dope, Mrs. Wade.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Dope. Hell. They've got a ten- dollar word for that, Marlowe. It is called sedation. And they

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: charge you... : He breaks off, looking with a sort of animal cunning Cc at Eileen. Then he lunges off along the hall to the study door. 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An intensely masculine room. A small arsenal decorates the walls. There is a desk with a typewriter and stacks of paper. There is a huge couch. Roger is making for it. Marlowe and Eileen enter after him.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I'm going to sleep here. This ol' couch is my friend. It receives me when nobody else will. Marlowe looks around. Eileen gets blanket and pillow from a cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: This is my room, Marlowe. Females forbidden, usually. I do my dirty work in here. See? Fine job for aman, ain't it...writing words on paper like a goddam stenographer. Sometimes I look to see if I've . still got ail my parts.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You seem to have done all right.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've done just dandy. I've got a great big beautiful house and a little small beautiful wife...

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Why don't you get some sleep now, Roger?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I'll sleep when I goddam want to. You married, Marlowe?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're missing. He seems about to settle down. Marlowe and Eileen start to go.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Hey, little buddy. Come here.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I like you. I liked the way you stood up to that little sod Verringer. I think maybe you'd be good for me. Why don't you stick around a while...keep me off the sauce until I finish the goddam book.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Wet-nursing is not in my line. Anyway, tomorrow or the day after, you'd throw me out on my ear.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Maybe you're right. Maybe I would. But you come back, huh? Come back anytime. We'll talk.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay, Roger. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe and Eileen enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you've earned a drink, Mr. Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I could use one.

dialogues.speaker: EILESN
dialogues.text: He's taken a fancy to you. Scotch or bourbon?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Bourbon, please. I'm sorry I can't say it's mutual.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you could he persuaded...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: To do what he asked? No.
Cc M4 CONTD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eo 38

dialogues.speaker: _ BILEEN
dialogues.text: He's a sick man. More so than you might think. He feels he's all through, that he can't write any more, He stares at the paper and nothing comes, and his success is fading away from him. He talks about killing himself. He needs help.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: If he's suicidal, he needs a good psychiatrist. And I'm simply not qualified.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid of him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're going to have to solve that problem for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Well. I'm grateful to you for all you have done. Did you have any trouble with Verringer?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE,
dialogues.text: Not really. He was trying to get a large sum of money out of Roger, before he let him go. That was why the brush-off this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Was it blackmail?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. Apparently Roger had made some promise to pay hin. I thought the whole business had better wait, so I got Reger out with his bank-account intact, but you may hear from Dr. Verringer. Getting late, and it's been a full day for everybody. Thanks for the drink.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: You will come back?

dialogues.speaker: M4
dialogues.text: Ni

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: And...if I should need you again...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You just call me. Anytime. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEW
dialogues.text: Good night. She watches him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe leaves his car in the driveway and walks toward his rural-type mailbox,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the hill above Marlowe's house, a big dark car with~ out lights suddenly starts up and swoops down.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He never opens the mailbox, but turns as the big dark car stops beside him. MARTY AUGUSTINE and some HOODS get out. Augustine is a big-time racketeer and he dresses the part; expensive, immaculate, and somehow just a little bit wrong.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: You kept me waiting, cheapie.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Augustine. I only see hoods by appointment. One of the hoods cracks him across the face.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: That's for being smart.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'd have got it anyway...it's ‘standard practice. What do you want, Augustine?

dialogues.speaker: N3
dialogues.text: na 40 ConrtD

dialogues.speaker: . . AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: I don't talk on sidewalks, cheapie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the hoods is going around turning on lights. Augustine inspects the room, his lip curling.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Christ, what a dump. What do you pay for this dump, cheapie?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Too much. And the name is Marlowe. Augustine's right hand man hits Marlowe in the belly and shoves him back onto the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: (to other hoods) Shake it down. The hoods begin tearing up the place, throwing stuff out of cupboards and drawers, turning back the carpets, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hey...! He begins a protest, but the right-hand man now holds a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Sit. Marlowe sits.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Look, Augustine. I don't gamble, I don't owe you anything, I don't even know you except by sight. So what do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: You're famous, cheapie. You got your picture in the paper. Every- body knows about you. You run the Mexican taxi service. . (a beat) You had a deal with Terry Lennox.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 41 eo Naé—- CONTD

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, deal? He was my friend. I took him,

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTIWE
dialogues.text: th ' Bulishit, cheapie. You had a ae deal. Some kind of a deal.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I drove Terry to Tijuana because he asked me to. I let him out on the street, he walked away, I never saw him again.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Then you tell me something, cheapie. You tell me why you went back.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Back where?

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: To Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How do you know I went back to Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: I made it my business to know, cheapie. All of a sudden I got an interest in you. The chief hood lays the pistol across Marlowe's head, a swift sharp blow to encourage him.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: What did you go back for?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I put a marker on Terry's grave. It seemed as though somebody ought to.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: You put a marker on Terry's grave. Jesus. And what else did you do in Otatocian? . MARLOWE . What did they tell you I did? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (2)
dialogues.text: The hoods The right to get up 42 _ MARLOWE (Contd) You or one of your bovs must have gone there...that's the only way you could have known.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: You were asking about Terry's effects...the stuff he left behind him. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARLCWE
dialogues.text: No special reason. It's just a thing you do.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: What was there?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE

It begins to come back to him. ...Roger's study, a lot of booze... He goes into Roger's bathroom. We hear water. running. He comes out again, looking more awake, hair combed and tie straightened. Marlowe shakes his head and wanders out.
