dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger enters.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Here you are. Why the hell didn't you answer me? Everybody gone?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Yes, Roger. Everybody's gone. Roger takes another pull on the bottle. He watches Eileen. She starts out of the room with a load of glasses, He knocks them out of her hands, sending stuff cascading all over the floor and nearby furniture.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: What did Verringer say to you?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Don't lie to me, you rotten little bitch. I saw him talking to you. :

dialogues.speaker: EILEEW
dialogues.text: All right! He said you wouldn't pay your bills and he didn't want you as 4 patient any more.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: He wouldn’t say that. Not about me. Marlowe. That shit Marlowe. Does he know why I went to Verringer?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: That shit Marlowe. You don't let your bed get cold, do you? One out, one in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, no...please...I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Everybody's welcome in that bed but me. You lie there and laugh at me... He starts beating her. Marlowe comes in.

dialogues.speaker: P10
dialogues.text: Pil

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (2)
dialogues.text: MARLOWE ’ Roger! Roger is too intent on his work and making too much noise to hear him. Marlowe gets between Roger and Eileen. He hits Roger as hard as he can and then waits for annihilation, with Roger looming over him like a mountain.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Big man! Roger seems stricken in some odd way. He seems to shrink in upon himself. All his truculence melts away.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You dirty bitch, you kept him here. Be does not go for Marlowe. Instead he turns on Eileen «verbally now,: not physically.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You remember what happened with the Lennoxes. Itcan happen again. I don't have to take shit from anybody! He charges out. Marlowe helps Eileen up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You all right? She nods. Marlowe helps her to a chair. The study door SLAMS o.s., violently.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOYER
dialogues.text: Marlowe comes from the living room. He listens...there are crashing noises from inside the study, Roger's muffled voice in an ecstasy of hysterical rage screaming obscenities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe and Eileen, as Marlowe returns.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He's wrecking the study.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: You showed him up, you see. He only beats women, but he wants to pretend, even to me, that he's really the big tough fearless male. Poor Roger, I suppose I ought to feel sorry for him. That's what all the books say.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Rot.. What happens next?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Usually he passes out, wakes up the next morning with a hangover and very little memory of what happened. Will you get me a drink, Phil, please?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What did he mean about the Lennoxes?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I don't know. He says so many crazy things.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sylvia Lennox was beaten to death. Was he threatening to kill you the same way?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: He may have been, I don't know. What am I going to do, Phil? I may as well face it, I've got a lunatic on my hands...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Separation. Divorce. Try and have him committed, which isn't as easy as it sounds. How well did he know Sylvia Lennox?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I don't know, I haven't any idea. He knew Terry, but I don't think...very well. It was a terrible tragedy. So senseless. ~

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Most tragedies are. Did you know the Lennoxes?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I'd met them, that's all. He didn't seem...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE, ,
dialogues.text: Like the kind of man who woul! beat his wife to death and then kill himself. No, he didn't. He has been listening to the noises from the study o.s. They have nowsubsided.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I think he's quieted down. You say he didn't know Terry Lennox very well, but he seems to have hated him rather viciously. How would you explain that?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I just don't know. And if you're expecting Roger to make sense about his personal relationships, don't. People like him don't need any real reason for hate. Didn't Mr. Lennox say anything to you...on all that long drive?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. Maybe he didn't have anything to say. (quoting Roger) ..-what happened with the Lennoxes can happen again, I don't have to take shit from anybody. Who would you say he was taking it from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Why don't you get a G@rink, Phil? You look as though you need one.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Perhaps I will. Did Roger ever talk about the Lennoxes? About Sylvia?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yet Sylvia was beaten to death, anc the same thing could happen to you. Was he having an affair with her?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Please don't ask me these questions. I can't answer them.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Was he having an affair with “someone you didn't know? Some- one who could have been Sylvia?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Where was he when Sylvia was killed? Eileen gets up and goes determinedly toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: To the bathroom. I need an aspirin. I need several aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: End of conversation. Eileen exits to the foyer. Marlowe fiddles with his drink, in deep thought. There is the SOUND OF A GUNSHOT o.s. from the closed study. Marlowe runs for the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: P13 THE FOYER
dialogues.text: Marlowe comes out of the Living room, Eileen out of the powder room which opens off the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot,

dialogues.speaker: P12
dialogues.text: Qu 66

dialogues.speaker: " CONTD, (4)
dialogues.text: He goes to the study door, tries it. It's locked. He pounds on it, shouts. .

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Roger. Roger! No answer. White-facead, Elleen speaks to Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: He may just be shamming. He's done this before, to frighten me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Roger? No answer. Marlowe kicks the door open, breaking the lock.. He looks inside, then turns and catches Eileen, to stop her going in.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Never mind, Eileen. This time he wasn't shamming,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eileen sits, looking stunned, with Marlowe hovering protectively. People are coming and going; lab men, photographer, ambulance men, cops. In the doorway of the room a DETECTIVE is huddled in private conversation with a man who holds a doctor's bag. The detective is making notes. The medical man leaves. The detective returns to Eileen and Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What did the M.E. have to say?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: What would you expect him to say, Mr. Marlowe? Now, if you'll just run through a few of these points in your statement, Mrs, Wade...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The lady's had a hard day, she's told you everything, why don't you let her alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ql

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: ’ (quite impersonal) This won't take long. I will read back to you your statement about your husband, Mrs. Wade. Please listen carefully. (reads) Roger was an alcoholic, he was very depressed about his work, he had threatened suicide on a number of occasions, I think he had been under some kind of psychiatric care. Question, Don't you know? Answer, He kept it secret from me, but Dr. Verringer can tell you. At the Sunnyside Spa. ts that correct?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: You hired Mr. Marlowe to get your husband away from Dr. Verringer‘s care. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hired Mr. Marlowe to find my husband. I had no idea where -he was at the time, and I was worried.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Roger left Verringer's of his own free will. He wanted to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Is this list of witnesses to your husband's behaviour at the party substantially correct?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: (looks at it) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Your husband was upset about Verringer's visit, he threw everybody out of the house, and then came back and found you alone with Mr. Marlowe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ql “contD (2) 68

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: He found me alone, period. I had asked Mr. Marlowe to wait because T was afraid. As you can see, I had reason.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The lady and I only met yesterday. Hardly time enough to develop a steaming passion. I told you, I was out on the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Your husband began beating you, Mrs. Wade. Do you know why?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: He thought, or pretended to think, that I was lying to him about what Dr. Verringer had said.

dialogues.speaker: . DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: About rejecting him as a patient.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: And when did Mr. Marlowe come in?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: As soon as he saw what was happening.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: He didn't fight with your husband?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: There was no need to. My husband was 4 coward, I suppose I have to admit that. He ran off to the study and locked himself in.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: And then you heard him breaking things.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: That was nothing unusual for Reger.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: You didn't try to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 69 No, we knew he was going to blow his brains out and we didn't want to interrupt his train of thought. Besides, we were busy having an affair. For Christ's sake! What do you want? Mrs. Wade was trying to wipe the blood off her face... se was in there taking aspirin when we heard the shot. Roger was a psycho. He talked to me about death...suicide...this afternoon. Beautiful, he said. Sweet, silken, swift. He seemed fascinated by the recent suicide of a man he knew.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Oh? Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Terry Lennox. Maybe that tipped Roger over the edge. Maybe it was something else. But he was ready and waiting to be tipped.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: And there was no more definite motive you can think of, Mrs. Wade, that he might have had for killing himself? Marital problems, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: It must be quite obvious that our marriage was not flourishing. But that was nothing new, either.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: We'd like you to come down to Headquarters and sign a statement.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Wade's can wait until tomorrow, can't it? I'll come with you.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Please? I really don't feel up to it.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: I guess that'll be all right. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 70 Cc Ql —sCONTD (4) DETECTIVE (Contd) I'll leave someone here with you. Come on, Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (to Eileen) This won't take long. I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: RL INT, FOYER
dialogues.text: A uniformed COP opens the door for Marlowe. As Marlowe crosses to the living room, the cop resumes his seat in a chair in the foyer, making a note of Marlowe's arrival and the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eileen and Marlowe, as Marlowe enters, There is a coffee service on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: ' Was there any trouble? € MARLOWE ‘ How could there be any trouble? They lock at all the angles, that's their job, but they can't make this one anything but suicide. How are you feeling?.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Blank. Terribly tired. No grief. eo grief at all. That's not right, s it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: May I have some of that coffee?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... It's just that all at once the house is so quiet. I ee) asked a friend to come and stay , the nightwith me...the watchdog : out there isn't much in the way . of company. Will you stay with me until she comes? ‘ MARLOWE Cc Of course. Eileen...you lied about : Roger. You were covering for him.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He killed Sylvia Lennox, didn't he? EILEEN © Can't you let that alone?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not until you tell me the truth. Roger's dead now, you don't have to defend him any longer.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Yes, he's dead. They're all dead. So what difference does it make?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Terry Lennox was my friend. If he didn't kill his wife, I want that known. And if it is known, perhaps the police will be more interested in finding out what really happened to Terry.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: What aes really happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Somebody killed him as sure as I'm standing here, and I want to know whe.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: But he confessed...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why would he confess if he didn't do it? And you know he didn't do it. So the note was a forgery. Why was Marty Augustine here last night? , {she looks startled, doesn't answer) I followed him from my place. He and his boys had a field day with me...what did I know about Terry, what kind of a deal did I have with him. Marty knows something. What did-he want with you?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 72 Cc R2 CONTD (2)

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Just what you said. Roger owed him money. He was getting impatient. Her thoughts are far away.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He didn't say anything about Terry?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay. Now, look, Eileen. I want the truth, and I don't give a damn about Roger Wade, his memory or his reputation, so stop playing the faithful wife. Did Roger kill Sylvia Lennox?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Yes. He killed her. € . Go on, tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: ' He was having an affair with Sylvia. You asked why he hated Terry Lennox --.it was because of her. He was jealous. And I think perhaps Terry had found out about them. I think perhaps Sylvia wanted to break it off. Roger went to see her that day, and I knew it. He didn't come back. When I heard that she'd been beaten to death I knew it had to be Roger, But... he was my husband, I felt I had to protect him. And then there was Terry's death, and the confession, and I didn't know what to think.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: . But you're sure now that Roger did it.

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Cc Yes. I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ‘Cc R2 sl

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Will you tell that to the police?

dialogues.speaker: EILEEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'LL go down in the morning and talk to Farmer,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farmer looks up from his desk as Marlowe enters.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: I can give you five minutes, Marlowe. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I want the Lennox case reopened.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: On what grounds?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I have new evidence. . . o.  , aS ARMER “Care to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Roger Wade is prepared to testify that her husband was having an affair with sylvia Lennox, and that he was with her on the day she died. He dis- appeared that same day. Further- more, Roger Wade was a psycho drunk with a special passion for beating women. A real nut. He killed himself last night.

dialogues.speaker: PARMER
dialogues.text: I know about that. And this is your new evidence?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: PARMER
dialogues.text: Nothing, except it isn't new. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: T2
dialogues.text: ul 76

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (2)
dialogues.text: VERRINGER (Contd) wife to know that he requires every so often to be spanked like a baby?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you decided to stop spanking him, and he killed himseif.

dialogues.speaker: VERRINGER
dialogues.text: Our relationship had deteriorated. He was building up a formidable resentment...a not unusual reaction, I was no longer able to help him. As to why he killed himself, who knows? Roger had long ago lost touch with reality. He lived in his own world, Who can say what made him want to leave it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes, who indeed. Well, I won't trouble you again,. Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe comes out, looking beaten. He plods to his car and drives away. : oo FADE OUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe at the telephone, making a call.

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello...Wade residence? This is Philip Marlowe again. Has Mrs. Wade come back yet? I see. Okay, thank you. I'11 try later. He hangs up. After a minute or two he reaches into a drawer and brings out the office bottle, gets up and draws a cup of water from the cooler. As he returns to the desk he picks up the automatic message recorder.

dialogues.speaker: RECORDED VOICE
dialogues.text: This is the Southside Finance Company. Your account is now two months in arrears. If you do not remit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: u1 vi

dialogues.speaker: V2
dialogues.text: wi 77

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE,
dialogues.text: Remit, remit! Keep your pants on. You are dealing with a wealthy man now. I own a portrait of Madison.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The portrait of Madison on the $5000. bill. It's lying on a table. We hear OVER a telephone dial spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe on the phone, making a call.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello, Eileen? Finally caught you. This is Phil. Yeah, I know, the lawyers and the red tape and all that jazz. You getting it straightened out? Good. Did you pay off Marty Augustine? I'm . glad to hear it. That was important. You okay? . Good, Uh...Eileen...I was just wondering if I could... Yeah, sure, of course...I understand. Later in the week, then. Take care of yourself. 'Bye. He puts the phone down and returns to the table. He has a drink and the inevitable cigarette. He sits down and picks up the portrait of Madison, staring at it moodily as though it could tell him a lot if it would only speak. It doesn't...and all of a sudden there are SOUNDS from outside, o.8....a car halting, feet thumping up the steps, a banging on the door. Marlowe hastily shoves the $5000. bill out of sight, under something. The door bursts open. Marty Augustine's Number One hood and a couple of others come in, Number One man has a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The boss man wants to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room, fairly large and bare, suitable for beating people up in. Harry the lookout and a couple of other thugs are there. Marlowe is pacing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cc Wi

dialogues.speaker: HARRY THE LOOKOUT
dialogues.text: Sit down.. You make.me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I make you nervous! What is this, anyway? I thought Marty wanted to see me...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY THE LOOKOUT
dialogues.text: Mr. Augustine will see you when he gets good and damned ready. So why don!t you just... He is interrupted by the opening of a door. Marty Augustine comes in with his Number One man. They shut the door behind them with a kind of unpleasant finality. Augustine nods to Harry and the others; they gang up around Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Now listen, Augustine...

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Shut up, cheapie. Okay. Time has gone by and I'm tired of fooling around. My boys are tired of following you...you don't go to very interesting .places, and Harry's getting ulcers eating at the dumps you eat at...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: I can't take all that chili size.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: So I'll tell you what. If you know anything, talk. If you don't know anything, that's too bad, because I am going to beat the living shit out of you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How the hell can I talk when I don't know what you want me to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: About Terry Lennox, cheapie. That's what I want to hear. Terry Lennox had a suitcase, remember?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: lim

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: . Yeah. What about it? . Augustine

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: That suitcase happened to have three hundred and sixty thousand bucks of my money in it. He was supposed to smuggle that dough into Mexico, but he wasn't supposed to disappear with it. I want to know what you know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred and sixty thou... Christ! In that suitcase?

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: In that suitcase, cheapie.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But I didn't know...I don't know... hits him.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: You don't think he committed suicide, cheapie, Neither do I. . A man with that mach bread in Maybe he was. his hands don't kill himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I told you...I thought he was... murdered...

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Maybe somebody found he had all that money and took it off him. Maybe you, cheapie, his old pal. Maybe you got it stashed somewhere...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Or maybe you helped him figure - out a way to get clear with it, for a split. Maybe he's still alive, sitting on the stuff and laughing at me. Maybe you're

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wl 80

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (3)
dialogues.text: AUGUSTINE (Contd) laughing at me too, cheapie, huh? Maybe you think it's very funny to steal three hundred and sixty grand from Marty Augustine? He hits Marlowe again, and then the others start in on him while Marty stands by watching. They are giving Marlowe one hell of a beating, in spite of his protests, All at once a door opens and a man comes in. He speaks apart to Augustine, who speaks to his Number One, who signals to the other hoods. They drop Marlowe, literally, and walk out of the room. Marlowe flops around feebly like a gaffed fish, trying to get himself together. Marty and some of the others come back into the room. Marlowe braces himself for a continuation of the beating, but they pay no attention to him. They're not even looking his way. Marty and Number One are talking together in low voices. They pass by Marlowe heading for a door at the other end of the room. Marlowe watches them.

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hey... What about me?

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTINE
dialogues.text: Go buy yourself a hamburger, cheapie. They all exit through the far door. Marlowe, completely at a loss, struggles to his feet and totters out the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe staggers out of a side doorway into the alley, moves along it toward the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the mouth of the alley, Marlowe pauses to lean against a wall and get his breath. He sees something o.s. that startles him. HIS POV . Eileen comes out of the front door of the building he

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: | o x3 x4 x5

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: has just left by the side door. car at the curb and drives away. She hurries to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The traffic is fairly heavy, moving slowly. Marlowe follows Eileen's car on foot, trying to overtake it, trying to attract her attention, but she is intent on the traffic and always one jump ahead of him, out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE AND COP
dialogues.text: Just as it looks as though Marlowe may catch the car at the next traffic light, he runs into a large uni- formed COP who regards his dishevelled appearance and unsteady gait with suspicion. He's been watching Marlowe's erratic progress, CoP What little game are you playing at, friend?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Somebody I know...in that car. I was trying...

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? How many did you have, friend?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I didn't have any. beaten up... I just got Eileen's car is irretrievably gone. CoP You ought to stay out of those places. Now, you gonna get yourself off the street or must I take you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. de signals a passing taxi and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls up in front. The house looks unusually dark, only a few lights showing.

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Wait, please. He goes to the front door, rings the bell. Presently a WOMAN opens it. .

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Are you from the real estate people?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What real estate people? I want to see Mrs. Wade.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: She isn't here.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: When do you expect her back?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I couldn't say. She just left me with instructions to get the house ready for showing.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight. The house is up for sale?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And where is Mrs. Wade?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: She didn't tell me where she was going: She just packed her bags and left.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I see. Thank you. He returns to the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe pays off the taxi in front of his house. He sees his mail box is hanging open. He goes to shut it, sees something inside, and takes out an envelope. Painfully, he starts up the steps.  ICs | c 22 o, 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe opens the envelope, takes out a note and a $500. bill.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Five hundred bucks. Suddenly everybody's sending me money. (reads the note) You never sent me a bill...I hope this covers. Thank you, Phil. Good bye. Eileen. (drops the note) Thank you, Phil. Good bye. He gets the $5000. bill out of its hiding place and puts the $500. bill beside it. He looks at them. Abruptly he slams open the door of a closet, takes out a suitcase and disappears with it into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, STREET
dialogues.text: Marlowe striding purposefully toward a building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jefe is at his desk going over some papers. He looks up startled as the door bangs open and Marlowe comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah...Mr. Marlowe! And what can I do for you? Marlowe strides up to the desk, takes out the $5000. bill and the $500. bill, and slaps them down on the Jefe's desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Talk. He sits down across the desk, waiting. The Jefe looks at the bills. He picks them up, He considers. He shrugs, and puts the bills in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded bus going along a dusty road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus halts to let off and take on passengers. Through a window we see Marlowe inside the bus.  Cc 25 26 27 84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . In a remote locale. Marlowe trudging toward it through the dust and heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasant, cool, whitewashed room with the blaze of sun outside, perhaps a garden in a central court. A man sits with his back to us, the picture of sybaritic comfort, smoking a cheroot, sipping a tall cold drink. The SOUND of an iron door knocker echoes through the place; it has a rather ominous sound, like the booming of a passing bell. The man rises and turns; we see that it is Terry Lennox, not disguised but somewhat changed...heavily tanned, a moustache, an altered hair- style. We follow him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: At the door, as he opens it. Harlowe stands in the doorway, hot, dusty, rumpled, tired.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: For God's sake. They stand staring at each other...Marlowe quite im- passive and refusing to disappear. Terry recovers somewhat from the shock. .

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Christ, Phil, I don't know what to say...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You might try Come in.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Well, of course. Of course. Jesus. I mean, I couldn't be happier to see anybody. I was going to let you know...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (enters) Sure you were. He looks at a woman's brightly-colored coat thrown over a chair (perhaps the same one Eileen was wearing when she came out of Augustine's).

dialogues.speaker: CONTD
dialogues.text: 85 How on earth did you find me? Don't tell me I left such obvious tracks...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You didn't. They were well covered. It cost quite a lot of money to dig them up. Can I have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, of course. Tequila? Lime? Soda? MARLOWE. And ice. It's a long walk in from the road. I'm thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Was it my friend in Otatoclan, the Jefe? Did he talk?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Don't hold it against him. He was sorely tempted.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I suppose he told you...I couldn't have worked it without him and the doctor. ‘The suicide, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He didn't go into any great detail, just admitted that th suicide was faked. :

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I was out the whole time, of course. The doctor gave me a shot. They used a blank cartridge to simultate the head wound. I've still got a powder mark there, probably always will have.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Small price to pay.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: When I was supposed to be dead they packed me in ice long enough (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ic

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (2)
dialogues.text: 86 TERRY (Contd) to take the photographa and the prints and so on. Then they smuggled me out of town and buried a coffinload of stones.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Very artistic performance. It must have made a dent in Narty Augustine's three hundred and sixty grand.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: He told you about the money.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He mentioned it. I never knew you were Marty's bagman. You . were smart to get the rest of it back to him.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: How did you... MARLOWE . They were beating the shit out of me trying to find out where the money was, and all of a sudden they stopped. Then I saw Eileen coming out of Marty's place. How is Eileen?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: She's fine. She went into town. Marty was looking for me. He came to Otatoclan...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. He landed on Eileen too, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: From what she says. He thought I might have left the suitcase with her. Anyway, I knew he'd never stop looking...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you used Eileen as a go-between. And everything turned out all right.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (3)
dialogues.text: 87 MARLOWE (Contd) Everything came up roses. Of course if Roger hadn't kilied himself and left a wealthy widow, it might have been different, but he did. You have the luck, Terry. You really have the luck .--She told me it was Roger and Sylvia having the affair, but it wasn't. It was you and Eileen. And that explains why Marlowe. Any news, any word of the beloved...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just thinking of some- thing.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Phil, I'm sorry I couldn't tell you the truth that night...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure, I understand. If there'd been any suspicion of a crime, I couldn't have taken you. Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: But I feel like a heel.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I said don't worry about it. I understand. Nice place you have here. I like the...the garden and all that. Very nice. You figure on staying here?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: We haven't decided yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, you can tell an old friend. You're dead, so you have to have a new name, a new passport. As soon as you get that, you and Eileen have the whole wide world to play in. Why aid you kill her, Terry?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why did you kill your wife? ‘TERRY As God is my judge, I didn't mean to.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Tell me about it, Terry. I've kind of bought an interest in the story, you might say.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Roger found out about Eileen and me, the son of a bitch. You have no idea what that girl went through with him...

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE,
dialogues.text: I have an idea.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Well, he fourid out and of course he went straight to Sylvia. ‘Told her the whole thing. She and I had a terrible row that night. Sylvia was screaming on about how much she loved me and how much she'd done for me, and what a loath-~ some character I was...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you beat her to death,

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: She wouldn't shut up, Phil. She started threatening me...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Did she know you were running Marty's dirty profits illegally over the Border?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Pretty hard to hide from your wife. She knew I had all that money in the house right then. She threatened to turn me in. You know what that (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (5)
dialogues.text: 89 TERRY (Contd) would have meant, not only to me but to Marty Augustine.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: A big bad rap. And you do have to be loyal to your friends. You owed it to him.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I guess I lost my cool. I hit her...Christ, Phil, that was a dreadful moment. Looking at her, and realizing...I panicked. I really did. All I could think of to do was run...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Taking the money with you.

dialogues.speaker: ' TERRY
dialogues.text: I couldn't leave it in the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No, of course you couldn't. When did you contact Eileen? To let her know you were alive.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: As soon as I heard about Roger's death. I keep in touch. Newspapers, radio. My Spanish is pretty good, you know, I've been coming here for years, The funny part of it is, Phil, you know...she really believed that Roger killed Sylvia? She really believed that. She thought Sylvia must have got him mad, told him he was crazy or something. Provoked

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Very funny. And I thought somebody had killed you. It didn't make any difference to Eileen, though, did it?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: . What didn't?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: When she found out it wasn't Roger. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 90 Cc 27 CONTD (6) MARLOWE (Contd) When she found out you really did kill Sylvia. Didn't bother her at all, did it? She still came running.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: We love each other,

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Phil, I am sorry if I made trouble for you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Oh, that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: You do understand, then?

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Cc Sure, I understand. And Terry believes him. He isn't afraid of Marlowe, _he doesn't worry about good old square Philip.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: I sent you some money. Did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: If you need any more...

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You and the wealthy widow will pay me to keep my mouth shut. a TERRY Oh, Christ, don't put it that way. You're my friend. You wouldn't betray me.

dialogues.speaker: . MARLOWE
dialogues.text: : I like your choice of words, Terry. Cc I really do. Begides, by the time

dialogues.speaker: CONTD, (7)
dialogues.text: MARLOWE (Contd) I could convince anybody outside of Otatoclan that that very con- vincing suicide was a fake, you and the lovely lady would be far away. Or I'd be dead. No, I won't betray you, Terry, I wouldn't think of it. By the way, aren't you the least bit curious to kmow how much it cost me to find you? How much it was worth to me?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: All right, tell me. How much?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Five thousand, five hundred dollars, exactly. He produces a.gun.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Phil. Not you, the true- blue all-American idiot, ever faithful. Anyway, you've got no reason to get sore. I didn't lie to you, you know. You just assumed...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just assumed.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: But Phil...the law...1

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Screw the law. He shoots Terry. Terry dies, still not believing it. Marlowe turns and walks out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marlowe comes out. Eileen is just driving up in a Landrover. She is astonished to see him.

dialogues.speaker: . EILEEN
dialogues.text: Phil... He walks past her without looking at her, as though she is not there. He walks away along the dusty road. She stares after him, getting out of the car. Then she turns and goes into the house.
